moves.1. e4: My first move will be the standard king's pawn opening, a favorite for most intermediate chess players.
moves.1... e5: The opponent defends the center by copying my move, so far this seems like a normal chess game.
moves.2. Nf3: I now attack his pawn with my knight, of course we're going to expect our oponent to defend it.
moves.2... d6: which he does, with his pawn, so far so good.
moves.3. Nc3: I now move up my other knight, to protect my pawn but to also add to my evil plan.
moves.3... b6: The opponent moves the b7 pawn, probably for some bishop attacks.
moves.4. Bc4: I move my bishop to c4, everything is in place now, let's see how my opponent reacts.
moves.4... Bg4: Exactly how I planned.  In his mind he made a good move because if I try to attack the bishop I'll mess up my castling side, or I could end up having a double pawn.
moves.5. Nxe5: I make the "wrong move" and give up my queen, hoping that he takes her.
moves.5... Bxd1: He did, like expected, and now I move in for the kill, it's mate in 2.
moves.6. Bxf7+: check, the king cannot attack the bishop because it is guarded by the knight.
moves.6... Ke7: the king moves to the only space available.
moves.7. Nd5#: checkmate, the king is trapped.  This is the famous queen sacrifice/fools mate.
